# Introduction to Zephaniah

## Part 1: General Introduction

### Outline of the Book of Zephaniah

1. Zephaniah introduces this book (1:1)
1. Yahweh will punish Judah and the nations (1:2–18)
1. Yahweh calls Judah to repent (2:1–3)
1. Yahweh will judge the nations (2:4–15)
    * Philistia (2:4–7)
    * Moab and Ammon (2:8–11)
    * Egypt (2:12)
    * Assyria (2:13–15)
1. Yahweh will judge Jerusalem (3:1–8)
1. Yahweh will purify, restore, gather, and bless his people (3:9–20)

### What is the Book of Zephaniah about?

Zechariah warned Judah and other nations that Yahweh was about to punish them. He also prophesied about how Yahweh would restore Judah. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/dayofthelord]])

### How should the title of this book be translated?

The traditional name of this book is “The Book of Zephaniah” or just “Zephaniah.” Translators may decide to call it “The Sayings of Zephaniah.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

### Who wrote the Book of Zephaniah?

Zephaniah wrote this book. But four different Old Testament people have the name Zephaniah. This Zephaniah was probably the great-grandson of King Hezekiah and a cousin to King Josiah. Zephaniah lived in the city of Jerusalem. He began to prophesy about seventy years after the prophets Isaiah and Micah. Zephaniah spoke Yahweh’s messages during the reign of King Josiah (about 640–621 B.C.), and just before Jeremiah began to prophesy.

## Part 2: Important Religious and Cultural Concepts

### Were the people of Judah faithful to Yahweh at the time Zephaniah started to prophesy?

Manasseh, the grandfather of Josiah, had been one of the worst kings of Judah. He led the people to worship other gods. After his death, his son Amon ruled for only two years before he was killed. Amon’s son Josiah became king when he was eight years old. Josiah learned to worship and honor Yahweh. Zephaniah likely began his work after Josiah had destroyed most of the idols and shrines of false gods in Judah. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/falsegod]])

### What country is coming to invade Judah?

Zephaniah often said a foreign nation would invade the kingdom of Judah. Zephaniah probably meant Babylonia. However, the Book of Zephaniah never names this nation.

# Zephaniah 1 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetic song in 1:2–18.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Prophecy

In this chapter, it is unclear whether these prophecies concern the fall of Jerusalem, the coming of the Messiah or the day of the Lord. It is possible that the prophecies reference more than one period of time. # Zephaniah 2 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetic song in 2:1–9, 12–15.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Prophecy

In this chapter, because the prophesied destruction is so complete, it is unclear whether these prophecies concern the time near the fall of Jerusalem or the day of the Lord. It is possible that the prophecies reference more than one period of time. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/prophet]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/christ]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/dayofthelord]])

Quote: Rally yourselves together and gather
Note: These two phrases mean the same thing. Together they intensify the command for the people to gather together in order to repent of their sins. Alternate translation: “Gather yourselves together”

Quote: before the decree takes effect
Note: This phrase refers to the punishment that will happen as a result of Yahweh’s decree. Alternate translation: “before Yahweh punishes you”

Quote: that day
Note: This phrase relates to the “day of Yahweh.” Translate as you did similar phrases in [Zephaniah 1:9](../01/09.md).

Quote: that day passes like the chaff
Note: The chaff is the insignificant part of the plant that the wind blows away. In a similar way, the day of judgment will pass quickly. Alternate translation: “that day passes as quickly as chaff blown by the wind”

Quote: before the fierce anger of Yahweh’s wrath comes upon you, before the day of the wrath of Yahweh comes upon you
Note: The prophet repeats the same phrase almost exactly in order to emphasize how terrible Yahweh’s judgment will be and the urgency with which the people must repent.

Quote: Yahweh’s wrath
Note: This stands for God’s intent to punish. Alternate translation: “Yahweh’s punishment”

Quote: Seek Yahweh
Note: Seeking **Yahweh** could mean: (1) asking God for help or (2) thinking about God and obeying him.

Quote: Seek righteousness. Seek humility
Note: The abstract nouns “righteousness” and “humility” can be stated as actions. Alternate translation: “Try to do what is right and to be humble”

Quote: you will be protected in the day of Yahweh’s wrath
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will protect you in the day of his wrath”
# General Information:\n\nIn 2:4–15, Yahweh announces his judgment on the nations that surround Judah.

Quote: Gaza … Ashkelon … Ashdod … Ekron
Note: These were the four major Philistine cities of that day.

Quote: will be abandoned … will turn into a devastation
Note: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize the complete destruction of these cities.

Quote: They will drive out Ashdod at noon
Note: Here “They” refers to the enemies of the Philistines. Here, **at noon** could mean: (1) the enemies will defeat Ashdod before noon or (2) the enemies will attack Ashdod at noon while the people are resting and unaware.

Quote: they will uproot Ekron
Note: The defeat of Ekron is spoken of as if it was a tree that was pulled from the ground and thrown away. Alternate translation: “they will take the people of Ekron away as if uprooting a tree”

Quote: the inhabitants of the seacoast, the nation of the Kerethites
Note: The first phrase explains where the Kerethites lived.

Quote: Canaan, land of the Philistines
Note: The Philistines were one of several people groups who lived in Canaan.

Quote: until no inhabitant remains
Note: This can be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: “until every inhabitant is dead”
# General Information:\n\nIn 2:4–15, Yahweh announces his judgment on the nations that surround Judah.

Quote: So the seacoast will become pastures for shepherds and for sheep pens
Note: This probably means that the Philistine cities are gone, and only open fields remain. However, the Hebrew meaning is unclear and is sometimes translated differently by modern versions.

Quote: sheep pens
Note: A sheep pen is a small area surrounded by a fence to keep the sheep together.

Quote: Their people
Note: Alternate translation: “The people of Judah”

Quote: lie down
Note: Alternate translation: “lie down to sleep”
# General Information:\n\nIn 2:4–15, Yahweh announces his judgment on the nations that surround Judah.

Quote: the taunts … the reviling
Note: “the taunts … the insults.” These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize that both Moab and Ammon have insulted Yahweh.

Quote: violated their borders
Note: This refers to crossing over into Judah’s territory in order to attack them.

Note: “as surely as I am alive.” Yahweh uses this expression to show that what he says next is certainly true. This is a way of making a solemn promise. Alternate translation: “I solemnly swear”

Quote: this is the declaration of Yahweh of hosts, God of Israel
Note: Yahweh speaks of himself by name to express the certainty of what he is declaring. Alternate translation: “this is what Yahweh of hosts, God of Israel, has declared” or “this is what I, Yahweh of hosts, God of Israel, have declared”

Quote: like Sodom … like Gomorrah
Note: These two cities were so wicked that God completely destroyed them with fire from heaven. These similes therefore refer to complete destruction. This can be stated explicitly. Note: “a place with thorns and a salt pit.” This describes a barren, useless land.

Note: “the city that is proud of itself.” This refers to the city of Nineveh, about whom Yahweh began to speak in [Zephaniah 2:13](../02/13.md).

### Prophecy

In this chapter, because the prophesied destruction is so complete, it is unclear whether these prophecies concern the time near the fall of Jerusalem or the day of the Lord. # General Information:\n\nIn verses 3:1–5, Zephaniah speaks Yahweh’s message of judgment to the sinful people of Jerusalem. The city represents the people who live within it. To make this clear, it may be helpful to replace the singular “she” and “her” with the plural “they” and “their.”

Quote: the rebellious city
Note: The nature of their rebellion can be stated. Alternate translation: “the people of the city who have rebelled against God”

Quote: The violent city is defiled
Note: Alternate translation: “The people of the city have committed violence and so I consider them unclean”

Quote: She has not listened to the voice of God
Note: The voice is a metonym for what the speaker says with the voice, and listening is a metonym for obeying. Alternate translation: “She has not obeyed what God has said to her”

# General Information:\n\nIn verses 3:1–5, Zephaniah speaks Yahweh’s message of judgment to the sinful people of Jerusalem. The city represents the people who live within it. To make this clear, it may be helpful to replace the singular “she” and “her” with the plural “they” and “their.”

Quote: Her princes are roaring lions in her midst
Note: Lions roar to chase other animals away from the prey they have caught. The princes of Jerusalem are spoken of as if they were roaring lions who were keeping the prey for themselves. Alternate translation: “Jerusalem’s royalty are as greedy as roaring lions”

Quote: Her judges are evening wolves who leave nothing to be gnawed upon in the morning
Note: Wolves are especially hungry before they hunt at night. The judges are spoken of as if they were hungry wolves. Alternate translation: “Her judges are as greedy as hungry wolves that leave nothing for anyone else”

Quote: Her prophets are insolent and treasonous men
Note: Alternate translation: “Her prophets do not listen to anyone and cannot be trusted”

Quote: have profaned what is holy
Note: Alternate translation: “have treated holy things with disrespect”

Quote: have done violence to the law
Note: Alternate translation: “have broken the law”

Note: These two phrases mean the same thing, and emphasize Yahweh’s righteousness even among the wicked people in Jerusalem.

Quote: in her midst
Note: Alternate translation: “among them”

Quote: Morning by morning
Note: This idiom means “Every day” or “Day after day.”

# General Information:\n\nIn verses 3:11–13, Yahweh encourages the remnant of Israel who survive the judgment.

Quote: In that day … at that time
Note: “When that happens … at that time.” These phrases here refer to the time of peace and restoration that immediately follows the day of Yahweh.

Quote: will not be put to shame for all your deeds
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “will no longer be ashamed of all your deeds”

Quote: those who celebrated your pride
Note: Alternate translation: “all the people who are very proud”
# General Information:\n\nIn verses 3:11–13, Yahweh encourages the remnant of Israel who survive the judgment.

Quote: they will find refuge in the name of Yahweh
Note: Yahweh’s protection of this remnant is spoke of as if he was a refuge or a fortress. Here “name of Yahweh” refers to his person. Alternate translation: “they will come to Yahweh and he will help them” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: The remnant of Israel
Note: This refers to the “lowly and poor people” of [Zephaniah 3:12](../03/12.md).

Quote: commit injustice
Note: Alternate translation: “do unjust things”

Quote: no deceitful tongue will be found in their mouth
Note: Here “tongue … in their mouth” represents the things that the tongue enables the mouth to speak. They can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “none of them will speak deceitful things” or “they will not say deceitful things” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: they will graze and lie down
Note: Yahweh speaks of his provision for the people of Israel as if they are a flock of sheep that grazes and rests in safety.
# General Information:\n\nIn verses 3:14–20, Zephaniah tells the remnant of Israel who survived the judgment that they should rejoice.

Quote: daughter of Zion … daughter of Jerusalem
Note: Here “daughter” refers to all the people who lived in the city.

Quote: Be glad and rejoice
Note: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize how happy they should be. Alternate translation: “Be very happy”

Quote: with all your heart
Note: Here “heart” refers to the inner being of a person. Alternate translation: “with all your inner being”

Quote: Yahweh has taken away your punishment
Note: Here to “take away” punishment is an idiom that means to stop doing it. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has stopped punishing you”

Quote: You will never again fear evil
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **evil**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “You will no longer be afraid that people will harm you”

Quote: In that day
Note: “At that time” or “When this happens.” This phrase here refers to the time of peace and restoration that immediately follows the day of Yahweh.

Quote: say to Jerusalem … Zion
Note: The names of these cities here refer to the people who live in them. Alternate translation: “say to the people of Jerusalem … people of Zion”

Quote: Do not let your hands falter
Note: To feel weak or helpless is spoken of as if their hands became physically weak. Here “hands” represents the whole person. Alternate translation: “Do not become weak” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
# General Information:\n\nIn verses 3:14–20, Zephaniah tells the remnant of Israel who survived the judgment that they should rejoice.

Quote: a mighty one to save you
Note: “he is mighty and will save you.” Yahweh is spoken of as a mighty warrior. Alternate translation: “he is a mighty warrior and will give you victory”

Quote: He will celebrate over you with joy … he will be glad over you with a shout for joy
Note: These two phrases mean the same thing and are repeated to emphasize Yahweh’s joy that the remnant is restored to him.

Quote: he will be silent over you in his love
Note: This could mean: (1) “he will quiet you by his love for you” or (2) “he will renew you because he loves you.”

Quote: no longer bear any shame for it
Note: Here shame is spoken of as if it was a heavy thing that a person had to carry. Alternate translation: “no longer be ashamed because of it”
# General Information:\n\nIn verses 3:19–20, Yahweh speaks directly to the remnant of Israel who survived the judgment and tells them that they should rejoice.

Quote: Behold
Note: This tells the reader to pay special attention to what follows. Alternate translation: “Look” or “Pay attention”

Quote: I am about to deal with all your oppressors
Note: It is understood that “deal with” means to punish the oppressors. This can be stated explicitly. Alternate translation: “I will severely punish all those who oppressed you”

Quote: I will rescue the lame and gather up the outcast
Note: Here the Israelites who suffered in exile are spoken of as if they were lame and outcast sheep. This can be stated as a simile. Alternate translation: “I will rescue and bring together the remnant of Israel who are like lame and outcast sheep” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: the lame
Note: This refers to people or animals that cannot walk.

Quote: I will make them as praise
Note: The full thought here is, “I will make them to be objects of praise,” that is, “I will make them to be praised by others.”

Quote: I will change their shame into renown
Note: The abstract nouns “shame” and “renown” can be stated as actions. Alternate translation: “I will cause them to no longer be ashamed, but for people to respect them”

Quote: At that time I will lead you; at that time I will gather you together
Note: These two lines mean basically the same thing and imply that Yahweh will bring the exiled people back to their homeland. Alternate translation: “At that time I will gather you together and lead you home”
